title: Synthetic Recap
body:
CHICAGO (AP) — On a night where points were a premium and defense dominated, one man reached a height no other player could touch. Michael Jordan, in a virtuoso performance for the ages, dropped 41 points on the Toronto Raptors, single-handedly outscoring the entire Raptors starting lineup and powering the Chicago Bulls to a commanding 97-70 victory in 1998.

While the final score speaks of a blowout, this was not a symphony of team basketball; it was a solo concerto played by its greatest maestro. On a night the Raptors’ starters combined for a paltry 39 points, Jordan’s 41 were a stark, brilliant contrast. He was the relentless engine of the Bulls’ offense, a force of nature against which Toronto had no answer. His points didn't just lead the game; they *were* the game.

Scottie Pippen provided crucial support with 14 points and a game-high 11 rebounds, while Toni Kukoc chipped in 13. But this evening belonged to His Airness. The Raptors, led by Doug Christie’s 14 points, were simply overmatched by the singular will of the league’s premier talent.

In a season of triumphs for the Bulls, this night stands apart as a monument to one man’s transcendent ability. It was a historic reminder that even on a struggling offensive night for his team, Michael Jordan could rise above, delivering a performance so dominant it felt less like a game and more like a coronation. He didn't just beat the Raptors; he overshadowed them completely.
